question_details.query: Considering different timber harvesting methods, which are most effective for increasing understory plant diversity?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, shelterwood harvesting appears to be most effective for increasing understory plant diversity. Six of seven studies found that shelterwood harvesting increased abundance, species richness and diversity of understory plants (Action 1223). Group-selection harvesting showed mixed results, with four of eight studies finding that it increased cover and diversity of understory plants, while two studies found it decreased understory species richness (Action 1224). General logging within forests showed moderate effectiveness, with four of seven studies finding that logging trees increased species richness and diversity of understory plants, while three studies found no effect (Action 1273). Single tree selection harvesting had similar species richness of moths to group selection harvesting or clearcutting but lower species richness than unharvested forest (Action 3867). Studies comparing different methods found that moth species richness recovered faster after shelterwood harvesting than after group selection harvesting or clearcutting (Action 3871).

question_details.query: What are the main benefits and negative impacts of using prescribed fire as a management tool in North American forests?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, prescribed fire as a forest management tool in North America shows mixed effects across different forest components. For tree populations, studies found that prescribed fire had variable effects on young trees - five of 15 studies found it increased density and biomass of young trees while two found it decreased new tree density, with eight showing no effect or mixed effects depending on tree species, location and fire frequency (Action 1220). For mature trees, four of eight studies found prescribed fire decreased tree cover, density and diversity, while one found it increased tree cover and three found no effect or mixed effects (Action 1217). Seven studies found that prescribed fire increased tree mortality (Action 1217). 

Regarding understory vegetation, eight of 22 studies found prescribed fire increased cover, density and biomass of understory plants, while six found it decreased plant cover, and eight found no effect or mixed effects (Action 1221). For plant diversity, 14 of 24 studies found prescribed fire increased species richness and diversity of understory plants, while one study found it decreased species richness and nine found no effect or mixed effects (Action 1221).

For wildlife impacts, eight of 14 studies found no effect of prescribed forest fires on amphibian abundance or numbers of species, while four found mixed effects depending on species, season or year of burn, three found fires increased amphibian abundance, and one found abundance decreased (Action 877). For butterflies and moths, three of four studies found that coniferous forest burned within the last 20 years had higher species richness than unburned forest, while one study found similar species richness between burned and unburned sites (Action 3877). Two studies found pine forest restored by burning had higher butterfly abundance than unburned forest (Action 3877).

After tree planting, two of four studies found prescribed fire increased survival and sprouting rate of planted trees, while one found fire decreased planted tree size and one found no effect (Action 1255). Bird studies in deciduous forests showed one study found similar bird species richness in burned and unburned aspen forests, though with changes in relative abundances of some species (Action 317).

question_details.query: How does the evidence for using shelterwood harvesting compare with clearcutting for promoting plant diversity and tree regeneration?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from action documents, shelterwood harvesting shows advantages over clearcutting for both plant diversity and tree regeneration. Three replicated, controlled studies in Sweden and the USA found that shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher plant diversity, lower grass cover and higher density of tree species compared with clearcutting (Action 1214). Six of seven studies (including five replicated, controlled studies) in Australia, Iran, Nepal and the USA found that shelterwood harvesting increased abundance, species richness and diversity of understory plants, as well as the growth and survival rate of young trees, with only one study finding decreased plant species richness and abundance (Action 1223). For tree regeneration specifically, three of six studies found that clearcutting increased the density and species richness of young trees, while one found it decreased new tree density and two found no effect or mixed effects depending on the tree species (Action 1222). In contrast, shelterwood harvesting generally showed positive effects on tree regeneration alongside its benefits for plant diversity. For moth species recovery, one study found that moth species richness recovered faster after shelterwood harvesting than after group selection harvesting or clearcutting (Action 3871).

question_details.query: After a wildfire, what are the documented benefits and harms of interventions like thinning and sowing seeds?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on documented evidence from multiple studies, post-wildfire interventions show mixed effects. For tree thinning after wildfire, documented benefits include increased plant species richness (found in two studies in Spain), increased cover of aspen saplings (found in one study in Canada), and decreased mortality of pine seedlings (found in one study in Israel). However, documented harms include decreased plant biomass (found in one study in the USA) and decreased species richness and diversity of mosses when logging occurs after wildfire (found in one paired-site study in Canada). For seed sowing after wildfire, documented harms include decreased number and cover of native species and decreased density of tree seedlings (found in studies in the USA). Three studies examining sowing herbaceous plant seeds in burnt forest areas found no effect on total plant cover or species richness. No evidence was found for the effects of planting trees after wildfire. Related interventions like using erosion blankets after seeding showed increased plant species richness in one study in Spain, while hydroseeding showed mixed results with some studies finding increased plant cover and species richness, while others found no alteration in vegetation cover or plant diversity.

question_details.query: In restored forest areas, what are some alternatives to using herbicides for controlling competing vegetation after tree planting, and how effective are they?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, several alternatives to herbicides exist for controlling competing vegetation in restored forest areas after tree planting. Covering the ground with plastic mats after restoration planting decreased the cover of herbaceous plants and grasses (Action 1239). Covering the ground with mulch after planting increased total plant cover (Action 1240). Managing vegetation by hand through selective weeding has been evaluated, with studies showing mixed effects on species abundance (Action 3714). Managing vegetation by cutting or mowing has been tested, with studies finding that areas where vegetation was managed by cutting had similar reptile species richness and abundance compared to areas with no cutting (Action 3713). Physical removal of mid-storey vegetation in forest resulted in increased mammal species richness and abundance (Action 2480). Surface mulch applications showed that mulched and unmulched plots had similar plant species richness over two years, though mulched plots were more likely to contain certain species after 20 months (Action 3248). In contrast, controlling vegetation using herbicides after restoration planting decreased plant species richness and diversity (Action 1241).

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence regarding the effectiveness of different methods to control invasive plant species in forests?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence regarding the effectiveness of different methods to control invasive plant species shows mixed and limited results. For herbicide control, one replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found no effect of invasive plant control using herbicide on the total native plant species richness (Actions 1229, 1314). For mechanical/manual removal, studies show varied outcomes: one replicated, controlled study in Hawaii found that removal of invasive grass species increased understory plant biomass, while another replicated, controlled study in the USA found no effect of invasive shrub removal on understory plant diversity (Action 1228). Additionally, one replicated, controlled study in Ghana found that removal of invasive weed species increased tree seedling height, but one replicated, controlled study in Hawaii found no effect of invasive plant removal on growth rate of native species (Action 1228). For prescribed fire methods, there is no evidence found for the effects of using prescribed fire to remove invasive plant species on forests (Action 1196). Similarly, no evidence was found for the effects of using grazing to remove invasive plant species on forests (Action 1195). For biological control using herbivores, no evidence was found for its effectiveness (Action 1277). One controlled study from Australia found that prescribed burning for lantana control resulted in smaller and less abundant lantana plants compared to unburned areas, and one replicated site comparison from Australia found lantana in a forest burned every three years produced fewer fruits and seeds with higher seedling mortality and slower growth rates compared to other management methods (Action 912). The evidence base remains limited with many methods lacking systematic study in forest contexts.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of public engagement strategies, such as awareness campaigns or education programmes, for forest conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents searched, there is limited evidence specifically for the effectiveness of public engagement strategies for forest conservation. For forest-specific interventions, we found no evidence for the effect of raising awareness amongst the general public through campaigns and public information on forests (Action 1157), and no evidence for the effect of providing education programmes about forests on forests (Action 1158). 

However, evidence from other conservation contexts provides some insights. A review of programmes in the USA and Canada argues that education was not sufficient to change behaviour, although it was necessary as a catalytic factor for economic incentives and law enforcement (Action 162). 

For species conservation more broadly, five out of six studies found increases in bird populations or decreases in mortality following education programmes, though in all but one case, education was one of several interventions employed. A replicated before-and-after study from Canada also found a significant shift in local peoples' attitudes to conservation and exploited species following educational programmes (Action 274).

For forest management specifically, one before-and-after study in the Republic of Congo found that 70% of central chimpanzees reintroduced to an area where local people were provided non-monetary benefits (including better education), alongside other interventions, survived over seven years. One before-and-after study in India found that numbers of hoolock gibbons increased by 66% over five years after providing local communities with alternative income, alongside other interventions (Action 1510).
summary_statements: There is limited evidence specifically for the effectiveness of public engagement strategies for forest conservation.

question_details.query: To protect forests from large native herbivores, how do wire fences and electric fences compare in effectiveness?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, both wire fencing and electric fencing show effectiveness for protecting forests from large native herbivores, though the research shows different patterns of results. For wire fencing, five of ten studies found that using wire fencing to exclude large herbivores increased the cover and size of understory plants, while six studies found no effect on the cover, seed density, species richness or diversity of understory plants (Action ID: 1230). Two replicated, controlled studies found that wire fencing increased tree density (Action ID: 1230). For electric fencing, one controlled study in South Africa found that using electric fencing to exclude elephants and nyalas increased tree density (Action ID: 1231). Electric fencing has demonstrated effectiveness across a range of mammal sizes, with nine of 11 studies finding that electric fences deterred crossings by mammals ranging from European rabbits to elephants, though two studies had mixed results with some fence designs deterring elephants and black bears (Action ID: 2439). Non-electric fencing studies showed that a high woven wire fence with small mesh, an overhang and an apron was the most effective design at deterring crossings by coyotes (Action ID: 2415).
summary_statements: Both wire fencing and electric fencing show effectiveness for protecting forests from large native herbivores.

question_details.query: What management interventions can be implemented to aid forest recovery after a wildfire?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the available evidence, several management interventions can be implemented to aid forest recovery after wildfire:

**Tree thinning after wildfire** (Action 1234): Studies in Spain found that thinning increased plant species richness, while one study in Canada found it increased the cover of aspen saplings. However, one study in the USA found thinning decreased plant biomass, and one in Israel found it decreased mortality of pine seedlings. One paired-site study in Canada found that logging after wildfire decreased species richness and diversity of mosses.

**Removing trees and shrubs to recreate open areas** (Action 2483): Studies in the USA found that removing Ashe juniper trees resulted in higher abundances of three rodent species, and removing trees increased use of areas by Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep.

**Mid-storey vegetation removal** (Action 2480): A randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that removing mid-storey vegetation increased both mammal species richness and abundance.

**Natural regeneration approaches** (Action 2634): A study in Canada found that natural forest regeneration increased moose numbers relative to more intensive management in the short- to medium-term but not in the longer term. Natural regeneration in former plantations or logged forest (Action 3876) showed varying results for different species groups, with some studies finding greater species richness and abundance of certain groups compared to managed plantations.

**Leaving woody debris after logging** (Action 3632): Studies in the USA generally found that leaving or removing woody debris did not significantly affect reptile species richness, diversity, or abundance, though one study found areas where debris was left had higher reptile species richness and abundance than areas where debris was cleared and burned.

**Prescribed burning on pine forests** (Action 318): Studies found mixed results, with some showing higher bird species richness in burned areas and benefits for open habitat species, while closed-forest species and ground nesters were generally adversely affected by burning.

question_details.query: What are the effects of tree thinning and logging on non-vascular plants like mosses and ferns within forests?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on studies conducted in Australia, Norway, Sweden, Canada, and Finland, both tree thinning and logging activities have predominantly negative effects on non-vascular plants in forest environments. For logging/tree removal, two of three studies found that logging trees in forests decreased epiphytic plant abundance and fern fertility, while one study found mixed effects depending on species (Action 1270). For tree thinning, four studies examining the effects on non-vascular plants found that three studies showed decreased epiphytic plant abundance and species richness, while three studies found mixed effects depending on thinning method and species (Action 1212). The evidence indicates that these forest management practices generally reduce the abundance and diversity of non-vascular plants, with some variation based on specific management techniques and plant species involved.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and harms of amending soil with additives like organic matter, lime, or fertilizer after planting trees?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the documented evidence, soil amendments after tree planting show mixed results with both benefits and potential harms. Organic matter amendments have demonstrated varied effects: in brackish/saline wetlands, adding manure to plots planted with tree seedlings had mixed effects on survival and growth over three years, depending on the tree species and manure dose (Action 3311). In freshwater wetlands, large amounts of compost amendment resulted in larger birch saplings three years after planting, but also led to plant communities characteristic of drier conditions and reduced plant species richness and diversity compared to unamended plots (Action 3310). Lime amendments showed potential negative effects, with one study finding that adding lime before restoration planting decreased the survival of pine seedlings, while another found no effect on oak seedling growth (Action 1259). Fertilizer applications after tree planting produced mixed outcomes: two studies found increased tree size, while one study found mixed effects on seedling survival and height, and three studies found no effect on tree size, survival rate, or health (Action 1260). Soil enhancers including fertilizer had mixed effects on seedling survival and height in one study, while combinations of soil enhancers did not increase seedling survival, height, diameter, or health in another (Actions 1153, 1260). Mixed organic and inorganic amendments showed benefits for soil properties including higher microbial biomass and activity, increased organic carbon content, and improved erosion control through reduced soil cracking (Action 902).

question_details.query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of community-based management for protecting forests in different parts of the world?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence for the effectiveness of community-based forest management comes from studies conducted in several regions worldwide. Two studies from Ethiopia and Nepal (including one replicated, before-and-after, site comparison) found that forest cover increased more in community-managed forests than in forests not managed by local communities (action 1152). However, one replicated, site comparison study in Colombia found that deforestation rates in community-managed forests did not differ from deforestation rates in forests that were not managed by local communities, or in uninhabited national parks (action 1152). Additional evidence shows monetary benefits provided to local communities for forest management had mixed results: one before-and-after study in Belize found that numbers of black howler monkeys increased by 138% over 13 years after local communities received monetary benefits alongside other interventions (action 1509), and one before-and-after study in the Republic of Congo found that most central chimpanzees reintroduced to an area where local communities received monetary benefits alongside other interventions survived over five years (action 1509). However, one before-and-after study in Rwanda, Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo found that numbers of mountain gorillas declined by 28% over 41 years despite the implementation of development projects in nearby communities alongside other interventions (action 1509). Community engagement in conservation activities has shown some effectiveness, with one site comparison study in Brazil finding that areas where community-based management of fishing practices was implemented had a higher abundance of river turtles than areas with no community-based management (action 3681).

question_details.query: What is the evidence comparing the effectiveness of using wire fencing versus electric fencing to exclude large native herbivores from forests in Africa and the Americas?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, there is limited direct comparison between wire fencing and electric fencing effectiveness for excluding large native herbivores from forests in Africa and the Americas. The evidence shows one controlled study in South Africa found that using electric fencing to exclude elephants and nyalas increased tree density (Action 1231). For wire fencing, two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that using wire fencing to exclude large herbivores increased tree density (Action 1230). Additionally, five of ten studies in Australia, Bhutan, Canada, France, Portugal and the USA found that using wire fencing to exclude large herbivores increased the cover and size of understory plants, while six studies found no effect on cover, seed density, species richness or diversity of understory plants (Action 1230). One study found wire fencing increased young tree biomass, one found it decreased young tree density, and one found mixed effects depending on species (Action 1230). For livestock exclusion using wire fences, studies in Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Israel, New Zealand, Spain, West Africa and the USA showed that four of eight studies found increased biomass, species richness, density and cover of understory plants, while four studies found mixed effects or no effect (Action 1205). Three of four studies in Mexico, Kenya, Israel and Panama found that excluding livestock using wire fences increased the size and density of regenerating trees (Action 1205).

question_details.query: What are the key benefits and negative impacts of logging trees on different components of a forest ecosystem?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, logging trees has varied effects on different forest ecosystem components:

**Understory Plants:** Logging generally benefits understory vegetation. Five of ten studies found that logging increased the density and cover of understory plants, while four of seven studies found it increased species richness and diversity of understory plants (Action 1273).

**Mature Trees:** Logging has mixed effects on mature trees. Three of seven studies found logging decreased tree density and cover, while two found it increased tree density and two found no effect. For tree size, three of six studies found logging increased tree size, while two found it decreased size. Tree species diversity was negatively impacted, with two of four studies finding decreased species richness and diversity (Action 1271).

**Young Trees:** Limited evidence shows logging can increase young tree density, with one study finding increased density and another showing mixed effects (Action 1272).

**Non-vascular Plants:** Logging negatively impacts non-vascular plants, with two of three studies finding decreased epiphytic plant abundance and fern fertility (Action 1270).

**Wildlife:** Selective logging practices show some benefits for wildlife. Studies found that primate densities were higher in low-intensity logged forests compared to high-intensity logged areas, and lemur numbers increased following selective logging (Action 1485). For insects, selective logging forests showed similar or higher butterfly species richness and abundance compared to primary forests, and higher moth caterpillar abundance than clearcut areas (Action 3867). Wildlife corridors retained in logged areas supported seven species of arboreal marsupials (Action 2651).

**Regeneration:** Re-planting native trees after logging resulted in similar species richness but lower diversity compared to naturally regenerating secondary forest (Action 3874).

question_details.query: How does the effectiveness of soil improvement techniques for forest restoration vary between studies conducted in Europe and the USA?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the available action documents, there are limited direct comparisons between European and USA studies on soil improvement techniques for forest restoration. However, several individual studies from both regions provide insights into different approaches and their effectiveness.

European studies show varied results for soil improvement techniques. In Finland, soil disturbance decreased understory vegetation cover (Action ID: 1252). In Sweden, tilling showed mixed effects on different tree species (Action ID: 1251). French studies found that vegetation removal combined with mechanical soil disturbance increased understory plant cover, diversity, and young tree density (Action ID: 1274). A Portugal study found that ploughing increased understory plant cover and diversity (Action ID: 1251). In Portugal, applying fertilizer after planting increased planted tree size (Action ID: 1260), while French studies found no effect of fertilizer on tree size, survival rate, or health (Action ID: 1260). Swedish studies showed that ground preparation treatments increased planted tree survival and growth rates (Action ID: 1263).

USA studies present different findings. Ploughing increased understory plant cover and diversity (Action ID: 1251), but did not decrease invasive grass seedling spreading distance and density (Action ID: 1251). Canadian studies (included with North American context) found that ploughing had mixed effects on young tree density, with some studies showing increases and others showing decreases (Action ID: 1251). Canadian studies also found that applying fertilizer after planting increased planted tree size (Action ID: 1260) and that ground preparation treatments increased planted tree survival and growth rates (Action ID: 1263).

The documents do not provide systematic comparisons between European and USA approaches, and most studies focus on individual techniques rather than comprehensive effectiveness assessments across regions.

question_details.query: What are the main alternatives to clearcutting for timber harvesting, and how do they compare in terms of their effects on forest plants?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The main alternatives to clearcutting for timber harvesting include shelterwood harvesting, selective harvesting/logging, group selection harvesting, thinning, and patch retention harvesting. Shelterwood harvesting increased abundance, species richness and diversity of understory plants, as well as growth and survival rate of young trees according to six of seven studies (action 1223). Group-selection harvesting had mixed effects on forest plants - four of eight studies found it increased cover and diversity of understory plants and density of young trees, while two studies found it decreased understory species richness and biomass (action 1224). Selective or reduced impact logging showed variable outcomes - logging trees in forests increased density and cover of understory plants in five of ten studies, while five studies found no effect or mixed effects (action 1273). Four of seven studies found that logging trees in forests increased species richness and diversity of understory plants (action 1273). For comparison, clearcutting itself increased cover and species richness of understory plants in eight of 12 studies, while two studies found it decreased density and species richness of understory plants (action 1222). Thinning as an alternative showed that forest species richness of moths was higher after thinning than after clearcutting and was similar to unharvested forest (action 3868).

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of different livestock management strategies within forests, such as exclusion, reducing intensity, or shortening the grazing period?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
The documented effects of different livestock management strategies within forests show varying outcomes depending on the specific strategy employed. 

For livestock exclusion strategies, using wire fences to exclude livestock from specific forest sections showed positive effects on vegetation in most studies: four of eight studies found that excluding livestock increased biomass, species richness, density and cover of understory plants, while the other four studies found mixed effects or no effect (Action 1205). Three of four studies found that excluding livestock increased the size and density of regenerating trees and the number of regenerating trees, though one study found livestock exclusion decreased tree density but not tree size (Action 1205). Complete prevention of livestock grazing showed that two of three studies found increased survival, species richness and diversity of understory plants, with one study finding mixed effects (Action 1206). One study found that preventing cattle grazing increased the density of oak seedlings and saplings (Action 1206).

For reducing grazing intensity, one study found that reducing grazing intensity increased the number of tree saplings, and another study found that reducing grazing intensity increased understory biomass (Action 1207).

For shortening the grazing period, one study found that shortening the livestock grazing period increased the abundance and size of regenerating oak trees, while one study found no effect on native plant species richness (Action 1208). One study found that the number of tree seedlings was higher following summer compared to winter grazing (Action 1208).

The effects on mammal populations from livestock exclusion varied: four out of eight studies found that excluding grazing livestock led to higher abundances of mule deer, small mammals and European rabbits (when combined with water provision), while other studies found higher densities of some but not all small mammal species or no effect on certain species (Action 2407). Two studies found more small mammal species on areas from which livestock were excluded (Action 2407).

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence for interventions aimed at reducing the risk or impact of forest fires?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The state of evidence for interventions aimed at reducing the risk or impact of forest fires is extremely limited, with most interventions having no evidence base and those with studies showing mixed or inconclusive results. For fire prevention signs, no evidence was found (action 1172). For prescribed burning, which is the most studied intervention, eight of 14 studies found no effect on amphibian abundance or species numbers, while four found mixed effects and three found increased abundance or species numbers (action 877). Prescribed fire effects on understory plants showed mixed results: eight of 22 studies found increased cover/density/biomass while six found decreases, and fourteen of 24 studies found increased species richness/diversity while nine found no effect or mixed effects (action 1221). Prescribed burning on deciduous forests showed minimal evidence with one study finding similar bird species richness in burned versus unburned areas and mixed results for specific species (action 317). For mechanical vegetation removal interventions, three studies found that mechanically removing understorey vegetation did not increase mammal abundances compared to prescribed burning (action 2482), while removing mid-storey vegetation increased mammal species richness and abundance in one study (action 2480). Creating fire breaks mechanically showed that areas with more recent/regular clearance had greater butterfly species richness and abundance (action 3881), and fire suppression combined with predator exclusion increased reptile abundance over time (action 3658). Many specific interventions completely lack evidence, including prescribed burning to reduce wildfire potential (action 1623), vegetation thinning to prevent wildfires (action 1764), zero burning policies near peatlands (action 1856), building fire breaks (actions 1766, 3080), raising water levels to prevent fires (action 3079), and prescribed burning to mimic natural fire cycles (action 1622).

question_details.query: What actions are available to legally protect forests, and what is the evidence for their effectiveness?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, several legal actions are available to protect forests:

Legal protection of forests (Action ID 1233): Two site comparison studies in Nigeria and Iran found that legal protection of forest increased tree species richness and diversity and the density of young trees. However, one replicated, paired site study in Mexico found no effect of forest protection on seed density and diversity of trees and shrubs.

Providing legal protection of forests from development (Action ID 1169): No evidence was found for the effects of providing legal protection of forests from development.

Legally protecting habitats (Action ID 158): Four studies from Europe found population increases following habitat protection, more positive population trends in protected habitats compared with outside, or with increased amounts of protected habitats. A literature review reported that a large number of cranes of seven species used nature reserves in China, whilst a replicated, randomised and controlled study from Argentina found that some guilds of birds were found at higher species richnesses in protected forests.

Adopting protected species legislation (Action ID 1201): No evidence was found of the effects of adopting protected species legislation on forests.

Designating protected areas (Action ID 3384): Four studies evaluated the overall effects of designating protected areas involving marshes or swamps. Two studies in China reported that the area of marsh, swamp or unspecified wetland in protected areas declined over 6-12 years. One study in Puerto Rico reported that protection had no clear effect on mangrove forest area. One study of a mangrove forest in Malaysia reported that it retained at least 97% of its forest area over 98 years of protection as a forest reserve.

Enforcing existing legislation for habitat protection (Action ID 2916): No specific evidence was found regarding enforcement of existing legislation for habitat protection.

question_details.query: What evidence exists regarding the effectiveness of legal frameworks and public engagement initiatives for forest conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Evidence regarding legal frameworks for forest conservation shows mixed results. Legal protection of habitat has demonstrated some positive outcomes, with studies finding population increases following habitat protection and more positive population trends in protected areas compared to unprotected areas (Action 158). Specifically for primate habitats, legal protection resulted in increased primate numbers in China for rhesus monkeys and grey snub-monkeys, a 34% increase in Hainan gibbon numbers over nine years, and lower stress levels in black howler monkeys in protected areas compared to unprotected forest fragments in Mexico (Action 1578). However, legal protection was not always effective, as evidenced by decreased numbers of Tana River red colobus monkeys and crested mangabeys in Kenya despite legal protection (Action 1578). For marine and freshwater mammal habitat protection, no studies were found that evaluated the effects of enforcing existing legislation (Action 2916).

Evidence regarding public engagement initiatives shows promising results for forest conservation. Community-based forest management demonstrated effectiveness in two studies from Ethiopia and Nepal, where forest cover increased more in community-managed forests than in forests not managed by local communities (Action 1152). However, one study in Colombia found no difference in deforestation rates between community-managed forests and other management approaches (Action 1152). Community-based participation in land management showed positive outcomes, with an increasing population of Himalayan brown bears in Pakistan associated with local community involvement in park management, and fewer farmers removing large carnivores in Namibia when engaged in community-based management through conservancy membership (Action 2395). Providing monetary benefits to local communities for forest management showed mixed results, with black howler monkey numbers increasing by 138% in Belize over 13 years, but mountain gorilla numbers declining by 28% over 41 years in Rwanda, Uganda and Democratic Republic of Congo despite development projects in nearby communities (Action 1509). Increasing resources for managing protected areas resulted in higher mammal species richness and greater occupancy rates in a well-resourced national park compared to a less well-resourced forest reserve in Tanzania (Action 2564).

question_details.query: What management actions are available to aid forest recovery after a wildfire, and what is known about their effectiveness?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Several management actions are available for forest recovery after wildfire, with varying effectiveness documented in scientific studies. Thinning trees after wildfire has been studied in five replicated, controlled studies across multiple countries. Two studies in Spain found that thinning increased plant species richness, one in Canada found it increased aspen sapling cover, while one study in the USA found thinning decreased plant biomass and one in Israel found it decreased mortality of pine seedlings (Action 1234). Post-fire salvage logging shows mixed results, with one study in Canada finding that logging after wildfire decreased species richness and diversity of mosses (Action 1234).

Seeding interventions have shown limited effectiveness for forest recovery. Three studies in the USA examining herbaceous plant seeding in burnt forest areas found it decreased the number and cover of native species and decreased tree seedling density, with no effect on total plant cover or species richness (Action 1236). However, sowing tree seeds specifically showed more promise, with one study in Brazil finding that sowing tree seeds increased the density and species richness of new trees (Action 1244).

Prescribed fire as a post-planting management tool showed mixed results. Four studies in Finland, France and the USA found that two studies showed prescribed fire after replanting increased survival and sprouting rate of planted trees, while one study found fire decreased planted tree size and one found no effect on size and survival rate (Action 1255).

Debris management is another post-fire action, with one study in Spain finding that removing burned trees and branches after wildfire did not increase European wild rabbit numbers compared to removing burned trees but leaving branches in place (Action 2478). Natural regeneration following disturbance showed time-dependent effects, with one study in Canada finding that natural forest regeneration increased moose numbers relative to more intensive management in the short- to medium-term but not in the longer term (Action 2634).

For logged forest areas, reseeding showed limited benefits. One study in the USA found that reseeded areas had similar reptile species richness, diversity, and abundance compared to areas left to regenerate naturally, and reptile communities in reseeded areas were not more similar to mature forest stands than those left to regenerate naturally (Action 3638).
summary_statements: Several management actions are available for forest recovery after a wildfire.
The effectiveness of management actions for forest recovery after wildfire varies and has been documented in scientific studies.
Thinning trees after a wildfire has been studied in five replicated, controlled studies across multiple countries.
Two studies in Spain found that thinning trees after a wildfire increased plant species richness.
One study in Canada found that thinning trees after a wildfire increased aspen sapling cover.
One study in the USA found that thinning trees after a wildfire decreased plant biomass.
One study in Israel found that thinning trees after a wildfire decreased the mortality of pine seedlings.
Post-fire salvage logging shows mixed results for forest recovery.
One study in Canada found that logging after a wildfire decreased the species richness and diversity of mosses.
Seeding interventions have shown limited effectiveness for forest recovery.
Three studies in the USA found that seeding herbaceous plants in burnt forest areas decreased the number and cover of native species.
The same three studies in the USA also found that seeding herbaceous plants in burnt forest areas decreased tree seedling density.
Those three studies found that herbaceous plant seeding had no effect on total plant cover or species richness.
Sowing tree seeds specifically has shown more promise for forest recovery than other seeding interventions.
One study in Brazil found that sowing tree seeds increased the density and species richness of new trees.
Using prescribed fire as a post-planting management tool for forest recovery has shown mixed results.
Two studies found that prescribed fire after replanting trees increased the survival and sprouting rate of those planted trees.
One study found that prescribed fire after replanting decreased the size of the planted trees.
One study found that prescribed fire after replanting had no effect on the size and survival rate of planted trees.
Debris management is another post-fire management action.

One study in Spain found that removing burned trees and branches after a wildfire did not increase European wild rabbit numbers compared to removing only the burned trees and leaving branches in place.
Natural regeneration of forests following a disturbance can show time-dependent effects.
One study in Canada found that natural forest regeneration increased moose numbers relative to more intensive management in the short- to medium-term.
The same Canadian study found that natural forest regeneration did not increase moose numbers relative to more intensive management in the longer term.
For logged forest areas, reseeding has shown limited benefits.
One study in the USA found that reseeded logged areas had similar reptile species richness, diversity, and abundance compared to areas left to regenerate naturally.
The same US study found that reptile communities in reseeded areas were not more similar to mature forest stands than those in areas left to regenerate naturally.

question_details.query: How does the effectiveness of community-based forest management vary across different countries according to the available evidence?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
The effectiveness of community-based forest management varies significantly across different countries according to the available evidence. In Ethiopia and Nepal, two studies including one replicated, before-and-after, site comparison found that forest cover increased more in community-managed forests than in forests not managed by local communities (Action 1152). However, in Colombia, one replicated, site comparison study found that deforestation rates in community-managed forests did not differ from deforestation rates in forests that were not managed by local communities, or in uninhabited national parks (Action 1152). 

Additional evidence from other countries shows mixed results for community-based conservation approaches. In Pakistan, involving local communities with park management was associated with an increasing population of Himalayan brown bears (Action 2395). In Brazil, areas where community-based management of fishing practices was implemented had a higher abundance of river turtles than areas with no community-based management (Action 3681). In the Philippines, after rural community members were paid a small incentive to protect Philippine crocodile sanctuaries combined with an education and awareness campaign, fewer crocodiles were killed than before community engagement (Action 3681). In Mozambique, during a community-based turtle monitoring project no killing of adults was recorded and fewer sea turtle eggs were lost to poaching than before projects began (Action 3681).

Regarding monetary incentives for forest management, results also vary by country. In Belize, numbers of black howler monkeys increased by 138% over 13 years after local communities received monetary benefits, alongside other interventions (Action 1509). In the Republic of Congo, most central chimpanzees reintroduced to an area where local communities received monetary benefits, alongside other interventions, survived over five years (Action 1509). However, in Rwanda, Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo, numbers of mountain gorillas declined by 28% over 41 years despite the implementation of development projects in nearby communities, alongside other interventions (Action 1509).
